Two Johns Hopkins junior instructors have received fellowships
for scientific research here, it was
announced by W W Trench, secretary of the Charles A Coffin Foundation. Lawrence J Reimert, a junior
instructor in physics, received a fellowship valued at $800, and Marritt
L Kronberg, junior instructor in
chemistry won a $500 fellowship.
Reimert, who is working for a
doctor's degree, will experiment in
the field of atomic physics. He hopes
to develop an atomic beam of light
which will make it possible to isolate
and determine the wave lengths of
lines otherwise hidden by the Doeppher effect. Such study will make
possible the measurement of the
ratio of the charge of an electron to
its mars.
Kronberg, who is working for his
doctorate under Dr David Harker,
will use his money to develop X-ray
apparatus for use in the determination of crystal structure. This apparatus, which may be completed by
next fall, will be used primarily in
the study of crystals of biological
importance.
These fellowships were two of
eight similar ones granted from a
$5,000 fund of the Charles A Coffin
foundation for the promotion of
scientific studies.

The Council seems to be
making a truly noble effort to take the student body
ever further along the road
to better administration and
government.
The amendment to the
constitution proposed at the last meeting should be
the last step in removing any dead wood, while still
keeping the basic set-up intact.
It might be wise, however, to consider modifying
that set-up to an extent whereby a better system of
proportionality of representation among classes and
schools might be achieved. There is too much danger
under our present system of a large group or school
being left entirely unrepresented as a result of the
machinations of our political guiding lights.
Of course, any move in this direction would involve an enlargement of membership in the Council.
Wieldiness must of necessity limit the extent ,of such
change. But the Council might well investigate a
system whereby all undergraduate schools are ensured
representation, and each class given a representation
deserving of its size.

Negro to the Hopkins Graduate school has as many
vs
thorny points as a cactus
simplicity
and is just as unpleasant to
handle. Emotional and rational considerations alike lead to stalemates or resolve
themselves into vicious circles. Whether one argues
finances, enrollment or the intangibles of liberalism,
proponent or opponent is right or wrong only according to original assumptions.
Validity in the debate of intangibles seems to lie
only in the question of whether or not opposition to
admission exists in the graduate b school. Obviously,
because of the not-to-be-ignored fact of close association of students in one school of a university, this-question had to be answered. And it was answered in a
recently held poll by a large majority vote in favor
of admission.
If the whole question were considered simply as
the case of one Edward Lewis, qualified for admission, there would be no bogging down in a morass of
abstraction and debate. And the best way to solve
the problem, it seems to us, is to return to simplicity,
examine the record of Edward Lewis without regard
to his color, and forget shifty ponderables which lead
nowhere. Such a policy could result only in admission, since Mr Lewis is particularly well qualified.

of marks. We fully apprea Few
ciate the need for some

modification in our present

adopted to which we take exception.
We make the primary assumption that one comes
to college to get an education. There is something
definitely wrong with a system in which marks or
rewards, rather than knowledge, are the criteria or the
incentive to study. This despite the fact that many
are forced into holding with the former concept
through years of sad experience.
The psychological effect of a material reward sys-

tern is an extremely bad one, forcing an individual
consciously or unconsciously to adopt a competitive
rather than a self-benefiting attitude. As much as
possible, the evaluation of learning on a basis of comparison must be eliminated. Taking the long view,
one's marks are of no value per se. As indicators of
ability they are at best questionable. Let them not,
ithen, be set up in the false light of being and ending
all. If they must be, let them be as innocuous as
possible.
The ideal system is one of no marks, or a simple
pass or fail. The Hopkins had an approach to this.
Unfortunately, those men forced into a competitive
field upon leaving the Hopkins came to much grief.
However, as we have stated, it is possible to deal with
this and yet retain the effect of the H S F system. A
detailed evaluation of each S, made a part of a transcript, achieves the purpose of affording outside schools
basis for comparison, yet need cause the student no
concern.
Such a system is not so involved as might first
appear. In effect, it is already efficiently operating in
several departments of the University, notably chemistry. It should be accorded due consultation and
thought.
The Board of collegiate studies has made a most
serious mistake in underevaluating the ultimate psychological effect of their proposed change. Thus in
one move is shattered a principle resulting from long
years of evolution. A further consideration might
well be in order.
